IndicatorDescription: Birth at fewer than 37 weeks gestational age.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 37 weeks gestation among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 37 weeks gestation among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing gestational age among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: Birth at fewer than 32 weeks gestational age.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 32 weeks gestation among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 32 weeks gestation among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing gestational age among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: Very low birth weight is when a baby weighs less than 3 lbs, 5 oz.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births with a birthweight less than 1,500 grams (3 lbs 5 oz) among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births with a birthweight less than 1,500 grams (3 lbs 5 oz) among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing birthweight among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: Low birth weight is when a baby weighs less than 5 lbs, 8 oz at full term.

Measures.MeasureName: Low birthweight at full term, Number
Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton, term births with a birthweight less than 2,500 grams (5 lbs, 8 oz) among residents of an area. Term births are those with a gestational age of 37 weeks or more. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.MeasureName: Low birthweight at full term, Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Number of live, singleton, term births with a birthweight less than 2,500 grams (5 lbs 8 oz) among residents of an area, divided by the total number of live, singleton, term births with nonmissing birthweight among residents of the area; expressed as percent. All births are restricted to those with a gestational age of 37 weeks or more. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: Death among children under 1 year old.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring at less than 1 year of age. Infant deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring at less than 1 year of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed as cases per 1,000 live births. Infant deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: Deaths among children less than 28 days old.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring at less than 28 days of age in an area. For more information about this measure, click here. Neonatal deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring at less than 28 days of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed as cases per 1,000 live births. Neonatal deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: Deaths from 28 weeks of pregnancy to 6 days old.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fetal deaths occurring at 28 or more weeks gestation, plus infant deaths occurring up to 6 days after birth in an area. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fetal deaths occurring at 28 or more weeks gestation, plus infant deaths occurring up to 6 days after birth, divided by the sum of fetal deaths at 28 weeks or more gestation and live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed per 1,000 fetal deaths plus live births. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics
Measures.DisplayType: per 1,000 live births plus fetal deaths

IndicatorDescription: Deaths from 28 days old to 1 year old.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring from 28 days to less than 1 year of age in an area. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths occurring from 28 days to less than 1 year of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed per 1,000 live births. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: People born outside the USA or its territories (including Puerto Rico).

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of people born outside the US or its territories (which includes Puerto Rico), divided by the total population; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of people born outside the US or its territories including Puerto Rico.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: Households with more than one person per room are considered crowded.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of housing units with more than 1 occupant per room, divided by the number of occupied housing units; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of housing units with more than 1 occupant per room.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: Homes built before 1950. Older housing can put residents at risk of lead poisoning.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of housing units built before 1950.
Measures.Sources: United States Census; American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Number of housing units built before 1950, divided by all housing units; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: United States Census; American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: Housing units occupied by their owner.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of housing units occupied by the owner, divided by all occupied housing units; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of housing units occupied by the owner.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: Asthma is a common disease characterized by breathing difficulty. Poor air quality and housing issues increase risk of developing and triggering asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma and symptoms in the last 12 months, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Beginning in 2017, indicator includes data imputed for missing responses.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma with symptoms in the last 12 months, divided by all adults and adjusted for age; expressed as percent. Beginning in 2017, indicator includes data imputed for missing responses.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma with symptoms in the last 12 months, divided by all adults; expressed as percent. Beginning in 2017, indicator includes data imputed for missing responses.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: The saliva, feces, and shedding body parts of cockroaches are an allergen and can trigger asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of respondents in an area that reported cockroaches in the past 30 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of respondents in an area that reported cockroaches in the past 30 days, divided by the number of respondents in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorName: Adults reporting mice or rats outside
IndicatorLabel: Adults reporting rats or mice outside their building
IndicatorDescription: Mice and rats are a source of household allergens connected to developing or worsening asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults reporting mice or rats outside their building in the past 90 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults reporting mice or rats outside their building in the past 90 days, divided by the number of adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Adults reporting secondhand smoke at home. Secondhand smoke, especially indoors, is bad for health - particularly for the health of children.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults exposed to second-hand smoke at home, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent. Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Anencephaly is a serious birth defect in which a baby is born without parts of the brain and skull.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with anencephaly and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with anencephaly and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: Spina bifida is a neural tube defect that can cause cause physical and intellectual disabilities.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with spina bifida (without anencephaly) and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with spina bifida (without anencephaly) and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: A rare birth defect where part of the heart is underdeveloped.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with hypoplastic left heart syndrome and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with hypoplastic left heart syndrome and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: Transposition of the great arteries or vessels is a congenital heart defect that involves abnormal arrangement of parts of the heart.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with transposition of the great arteries and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with transposition of the great arteries and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorName: Cleft lip (with or without cleft palate)
IndicatorLabel: Cleft lip (with or without cleft palate)
IndicatorDescription: Cleft lip is a birth defect that occurs when a baby's lip does not form properly during pregnancy.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with cleft lip with or without cleft palate and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with cleft lip with or without cleft palate and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: Cleft palate is a birth defect that occurs when a baby's mouth does not form properly during pregnancy.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with cleft palate without cleft lip and reported the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with cleft palate without cleft lip and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: A birth defect in male babies where the urethra opening is not at the tip of the penis.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with hypospadias and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with hypospadias and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: A birth defect where there is a hole beside the belly button and the baby's intestines or other organs are outside the baby's body.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with gastroschisis and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with gastroschisis and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: Upper limb deficiencies include undergrowth, overgrowth, failure of formation, and other variations or deficiencies in the upper limbs.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with upper limb deficiencies and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with upper limb deficiencies and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: Lower limb deficiencies include undergrowth, overgrowth, failure of formation, and other variations or deficiencies in the lower limbs.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with lower limb deficiencies and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with lower limb deficiencies and reported the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: Down syndrome is a condition in which a person has an extra chromosome. It causes delays in physical growth, and intellectual disabilities.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 to women less than 35 years old and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 to women less than 35 years old and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: Down syndrome is a condition in which a person has an extra chromosome. It causes delays in physical growth, and intellectual disabilities.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 to women 35 years or older and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of live births diagnosed with Down Syndrome / Trisomy 21 to women 35 years or older and reported to the NYS CMR over the 3 year period, divided by the number of live births over the same period; expressed per 10,000.
Measures.Sources: New York State Congenital Malformations Registry (CMR)

IndicatorDescription: A carbon monoxide incident is a leak where the Fire Department measures at least 1 ppm at the scene.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of carbon monoxide incidents where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene.
Measures.Sources: Fire Department of New York City (FDNY) Carbon Monoxide Incidents

Measures.MeasureName: Carbon monoxide incidents, Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of carbon monoxide incidents in an area, where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene, divided by the number of buildings in the area; expressed as incidents per 10,000 buildings.
Measures.Sources: New York City Primary Land Use Tax Lot Output (PLUTO™) Property Characteristic Data; Fire Department of New York City (FDNY) Carbon Monoxide Incidents

IndicatorDescription: Cracks or holes are a maintenance deficiency linked to the presence of mice, rats, and cockroaches - which can harm residents' health.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported cracks or holes in the home.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported cracks or holes in the home, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorDescription: Older housing (built before 1960) that has peeling paint can put residents at risk of lead poisoning, due to lead paint. Lead paint was banned from household paints in New York City in 1960 and in the USA in 1978.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that were built before 1960 and had peeling paint in areas greater than 8.5" x 11".
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that were built before 1960 and had peeling paint n areas greater than 8.5" x 11", divided by the total number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorDescription: Leaks are a maintenance deficiency that can harm health by introducing mold, which can worsen respiratory conditions like asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported leaks coming from outside the unit, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported leaks coming from outside the unit, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorLabel: Homes with 3 or more housing problems
IndicatorDescription: Homes with housing problems can threaten the health of the people who live there.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households reporting three or more maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit).
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area reporting three or more maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit), divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorName: Homes near structures rated good or excellent
IndicatorLabel: Homes near structures rated good or excellent
IndicatorDescription: Building quality predicts the number of housing maintenance deficiencies in a residence that place residents at increased risk of acute or chronic health problems.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that rated their neighborhood structures as good or excellent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that rated their neighborhood structures as good or excellent, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorDescription: The need for supplemental heat may mean a building's main heat source doesn't work - and can indicate the presence of other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that needed to use a secondary source of heat in addition to their primary source.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that needed to use a secondary source of heat in addition to their primary source, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorName: Homes with mice or rats in the building
IndicatorLabel: Homes with mice or rats in the building
IndicatorDescription: The presence of mice or rats in the home is often associated with poor housing maintenance. These pests can contaminate food and worsen asthma.

Measures.MeasureName: Mice or rats (in the building), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported mice or rats in their building in the past 90 days.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.MeasureName: Mice or rats (in the building), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported mice or rats in their building in the past 90 days, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorDescription: Ozone is a common air pollutant that can harm breathing and worsen asthma and other respiratory conditions.

Measures.how_calculated: When the daily average ozone levels are above 150 on EPA's Air Quality Index (AQI), the day is an "Action Day for the General Population".
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.how_calculated: When the daily average ozone levels are between 101 and 150 on EPA's Air Quality Index (AQI), the day is an "Action Day for Sensitive Groups" (people with lung disease, children, older adults, people who are active outdoors or have certain genetic variants).
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data; United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

IndicatorDescription: Fine particles are emitted by vehicles, building boilers, and other combustion - and are a major form of air pollution that harms health.

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 (Fine particles) action days, PM2.5 annual average
Measures.how_calculated: This measure is calculated by averaging PM2.5 levels at each monitor, weighted by the number of samples in each quarter, then taking the weighted average of all monitors in the geographic area.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 (Fine particles) action days, Sensitive groups
Measures.how_calculated: When the daily average PM2.5 levels are between 101 and 150 on EPA's Air Quality Index (AQI), the day is an "Action Day for Sensitive Groups" (people with heart or lung disease, children, older adults and people of lower socieconomic status). Folks in these groups may need to take action to protect their health on these days. An AQI value of 100 generally corresponds to a pollution level that is equal to the daily federal air quality standard.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 (Fine particles) action days, General population
Measures.how_calculated: When the daily average PM2.5 levels are above 150 on EPA's Air Quality Index (AQI), the day is an "Action Day for the General Population".
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 (Fine particles) action days, PM2.5 98th percentile
Measures.how_calculated: 98% of PM2.5 measurements taken at New York City's EPA Air Quality Stations are below this value over the past three years. This value is one of the PM2.5 Federal Air Quality Standards. The standard is 65 mcg per cubic meter.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

IndicatorDescription: Breast cancer is a common cancer. It is more common among females.

Measures.MeasureName: Breast cancer (in females), Average annual number (under age 50)
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents, less than 50 yrs old, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by 5.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Breast cancer (in females), Age-adjusted rate (under age 50)
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents, less than 50 yrs old, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: United States Census; New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Breast cancer (in females), Average annual number (age 50+)
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents, 50 yrs and older, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by 5.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents, 50 Yrs and Older, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

IndicatorDescription: Cancers in the lung or bronchus.

Measures.MeasureName: Lung and bronchus cancer, Average annual number (Males)
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Lung and bronchus cancer, Age-adjusted rate (Males)
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 male residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Lung and bronchus cancer, Average annual number (Females)
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Lung and bronchus cancer, Age-adjusted rate (Females)
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Lung and bronchus cancer, Average annual number
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Lung and bronchus cancer, Age-adjusted rate
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with lung and bronchus cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

IndicatorDescription: Cancer of the pancreas.

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of male residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 male residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of female residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Cancer Registry

Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of residents diagnosed with pancreatic cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). IndicatorDescription: Asthma hospitalizations are more severe asthma outcomes. They're often clustered in high-poverty neighborhoods, where disinvestment and poor housing conditions expose residents to triggers.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children up to 4 years old. A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasureName: Asthma hospitalizations (age 4 and under), Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorDescription: Households that report using a regular exterminator service.

Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported regular exterminator service, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorDescription: Action days for sensitive groups are counted when either ozone or PM2.5 levels are above 100, and for the general population when levels are above 150.

Measures.MeasureName: Air quality action days, General population
Measures.how_calculated: An AQI value of 100 corresponds to the current U.S. standard for a pollutant (0.075 ppm for ozone, 35 ug/m3 for PM2.5), and deviations from the standard are expressed as the pollutant concentration divided by the standard and multiplied by 100. Advisory days for the general public are counted when either ozone or PM2.5 levels are above 150.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

Measures.MeasureName: Air quality action days, Sensitive groups
Measures.how_calculated: An AQI value of 100 corresponds to the current U.S. standard for a pollutant (0.075 ppm for ozone, 35 ug/m3 for PM2.5), and deviations from the standard are expressed as the pollutant concentration divided by the standard and multiplied by 100. Advisory days for sensitive groups are counted when either ozone or PM2.5 levels are above 100.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

IndicatorDescription: Pesticides targeting insects, applied by professional exterminators or licensed maintenance staff.

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of insecticides, Liquid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, mechanical, or termiticide.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of insecticides, Solid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, "mechanical", or termiticide.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of herbicides, Liquid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as fertilizer, herbicide, defoliant, herbicide terrestrial, herbicide aquatic, or plant growth regulator.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of herbicides, Solid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as fertilizer, herbicide, defoliant, herbicide terrestrial, herbicide aquatic, or plant growth regulator.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

IndicatorDescription: Pesticides targeting type of fungus such as mold or plant blight applied by professional exterminators or licensed maintenance staff. These are often applied to protect landscaping and golf course grasses.

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of fungicides, Solid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as fungistat, fungicide, fungicide/fungistat, or fungicide/nematicide. Excludes products classified as disinfectant, sanitizer, microbicide, microbicide/microbistat, insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of fungicides, Liquid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as fungistat, fungicide, fungicide/fungistat, or fungicide/nematicide. Excludes products classified as disinfectant, sanitizer, microbicide, microbicide/microbistat, insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

IndicatorDescription: Pesticides of this chemical class used to target insects, applied by professional exterminators or licensed maintenance staff. Organophosphates are acutely toxic and present a significant health risk from human exposure.

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of insecticides (Organophosphate), Liquid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class organophosphorous compound.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of insecticides (Organophosphate), Solid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class organophosphorous compound.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

IndicatorDescription: Pyrethroids and Pyrethrins are less acutely toxic than some other insecticide classes. But based on how they are broadly applied, they can present a significant risk of human exposure. These chemicals can also cause a respiratory allergic reaction and short term irritation to the skin and face.

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of insecticides (Pyrethroid/Pyrethrin), Liquid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class pyrethrin or pyrethroid.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of insecticides (Pyrethroid/Pyrethrin), Solid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class pyrethrin or pyrethroid.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

IndicatorDescription: Carbamates are acutely toxic and present a significant health risk from human exposure.

Measures.how_calculated: Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class N-methyl carbamate
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredients of the chemical class N-methyl carbamate
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

IndicatorDescription: Pesticides targeting insects, but have low toxicity or low potential for human exposure, applied by professionally licensed exterminators and maintenance staff.

Measures.MeasureName: Commercial use of "Best Practice" products, Solid products
Measures.how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; having the term bait or gel in the product name, or containing active ingredients boric acid, disodium octaborate tetrahydrate, sodium tetraborate (pentahydrate), indoxacarb, silica gel, diatomaceous earth, (Z)-9-tricosene, S-methoprene, spinosad, hydramethylnon, pyriproxyfen, or fipronil; and not containing active ingredients of the chemical classes pyrethrins, pyrethroids, N-methyl carbamates or organophosphorous compounds.
Measures.Sources: New York State Pesticide Sales and Use Registry (PSUR)

IndicatorDescription: Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that affects how blood flows through the heart.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of people for whom poverty status is determined, whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level.

IndicatorDescription: Adults without a smoke-free home policy. A smoke-free home policy can limit people's exposure to secondhand smoke, which is especially dangerous to children.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in an area without a policy that prohibits smoking anywhere in the home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults without a policy that prohibits smoking anywhere in the home, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Adults who are current smokers. Cigarette smoking is the leading cause of preventable deaths in the USA. It causes many diseases and greatly harms health.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who report current, active smoking, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in an area who report current, active smoking, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Adults reporting secondhand smoke at work. Secondhand smoke, especially indoors, is bad for health.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults exposed to second-hand smoke at work, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time at work are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at work.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at work, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent. Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time at work are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at work.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: High school students who smoked in the past 30 days (from when they were surveyed). Cigarette smoking is the leading cause of preventable deaths in the USA. It causes many diseases and greatly harms health.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of high school students who smoked cigarettes on one or more of the past 30 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Youth Risk Behavioral Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of high school students who smoked cigarettes on one or more of the past 30 days, divided by total number of high school students; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Youth Risk Behavioral Survey

IndicatorDescription: Fine particles are emitted by vehicles, building boilers, and other combustion - and are a major form of air pollution that harms health.

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. In NYC, fine particulate matter is measured in units of micrograms per cubic meter of air.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specific time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and the 10th percentile identified. In NYC, fine particulate matter is measured in units of micrograms per cubic meter of air.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specific time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and the 90th percentile identified. In NYC, fine particulate matter is measured in units of micrograms per cubic meter of air.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

IndicatorDescription: Black carbon is a major component of fine particles in the air. Fine particles are easily inhaled and contribute to both short-term acute health effects, as well as long-term chronic illness.

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. Black carbon levels are estimated using a method that measures absorbance.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specific time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood, and the 10th percentile identified. Black carbon levels are estimated using a method that measures absorbance.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specific time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and the 90th percentile identified. Black carbon levels are estimated using a method that measures absorbance.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

IndicatorDescription: Nitrogen dioxide is a pollutant formed by combusion that damage lung tissue, cause breathing problems, and contribute to smog and acid rain.

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. The gaseous pollutants in NYC are measured in units of parts per billion.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specific time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and the 10th percentile identified. The gaseous pollutants in NYC are measured in units of parts per billion.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specific time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and the 90th percentile identified. The gaseous pollutants in NYC are measured in units of parts per billion.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

IndicatorDescription: Sulfur dioxide comes from burning some kinds of fuel oil. As an air pollutant, it can can worsen lung diseases.

Measures.how_calculated: Data collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then smoothed using GIS, assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood, and averaged. The gaseous pollutants in NYC are measured in units of parts per billion.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specific time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and the 10th percentile identified. The gaseous pollutants in NYC are measured in units of parts per billion.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specific time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and the 90th percentile identified. The gaseous pollutants in NYC are measured in units of parts per billion.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Air Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. In NYC, ozone is measured in units of parts per billion (ppb).

IndicatorDescription: Nitrates are found in water near where nitrogen-based fertilizers are used. Infants who are fed formula made with water containing nitrates over 10 mg/L sometimes became seriously ill.

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from entry points to the drinking water distribution system. Samples may not be required every year; the most recent available sample result is used to calculate the average. If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year and compared to the Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL), which is the highest level of a contamimant that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from entry points to the drinking water distribution system. Samples may not be required every year; the most recent available sample result is used to calculate the maximum concentration. If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each year and compared to the Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL), which is the highest level of a contamimant that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The number of nitrate samples taken at entry points to the distribution system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Number of sampling locations.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The highest level of nitrate that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

IndicatorDescription: Disinfection by-products are chemicals that can form when a disinfectant such as chlorine reacts with naturally occurring organic matter and other substances in the source water. Current research is investigating whether there are health effects from chronic exposure to the by-products of water disinfection.

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each year.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The number of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) samples taken throughout the distribution system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Number of sampling total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) locations.

Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each quarter.

Measures.how_calculated: The highest level of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). IndicatorName: Asthma emergency department visits (age 4 and under)
IndicatorDescription: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Things like smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander can trigger asthma.

Measures.MeasureName: Asthma ED visits (age 4 and under), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old. ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasureName: Asthma ED visits (age 4 and under), Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorDescription: People who are overweight or obese are at increased risk for heart disease and diabetes.

A BMI between 25 and 29.9 is classified as overweight, and a BMI of 30 or greater is classified as obese.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults classified as overweight or obese; based on the Body Mass Index (BMI) calculated from self-reported weight and height, expressed as a percent. A BMI between 25 and 29.9 is classified as overweight, and a BMI of 30 or greater is classified as obese.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: An A grade is the highest a restaurant can score in a health inspection. It indicates a well maintained restaurant with clean and safe food handling and storage practices, minimizing the risk of food poisoning.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of currently operating restaurants with an "A" grade in the window.
Measures.Sources: New York City Food Safety and Community Sanitation Tracking System

Measures.how_calculated: Percent of currently operating restaurants with an "A" grade in the window, divided by all currently operating restaurants, including those with a "Grade Pending" in the window.
Measures.Sources: New York City Food Safety and Community Sanitation Tracking System

IndicatorDescription: Adults reporting their neighborhood is safe from crime. Whether people perceive their neighborhood as safe can affect whether they will spend time outside, use parks, and use active and sustainable forms of transportation. It can also affect mental well-being.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported living in a neighborhood safe from crime rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported living in a neighborhood safe from crime, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Hot weather kills more people than all other extreme weather combined. This measure includes only deaths directly attributed to heat on death certificates, which represent a small proportion of all heat-related deaths.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths during warm season months of May-September with an underlying or contributing cause that includes excessive natural heat (ICD10 code X30) and effects of heat and light (ICD10 code T67), among NYC residents. This number includes only deaths directly attributed to heat on death certificates, which represent a small proportion of all heat-related deaths. Heat can exacerbate chronic conditions, resulting in death from natural causes that may not be labeled as heat-related on a death certificate (also called "excess mortality.")
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorName: Heat stress: yearly emergency department visits
IndicatorDescription: ED visits due to heat-related illnesses, such as heat stroke and heat exhaustion, represent part of the public health burden of extreme heat.

Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasureName: Heat ED visits, Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

IndicatorDescription: Heat stress hospitalizations weather are part of the public health burden due to hot weather.

Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases admitted before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. The numbers are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases admitted before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Numbers are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates, to produce an age-adjusted rate. Quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases admitted before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

IndicatorDescription: Bicycle injury hospitalizations can indicate the overall safety of cycling in the city - for transporation or other purposes.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC nonfatal hospitalizations related to bicycle injuries among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM injury codes: V01-V99. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Citywide totals include both NYC residents and non-residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS), 2016, updated January 2018.

Measures.how_calculated: Counts are the number of NYC nonfatal hospitalizations related to bicycle injuries among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM injury codes: V01-V99. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Citywide totals include both NYC residents and non-residents. Counts are summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population of NYC residents in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) inpatient data 2016, updated January 2018. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2018, updated September 2019.

IndicatorDescription: Adults reporting that they drink 1 or more sugary drinks per day. Sugary drinks contribute to an unhealthy, high-calorie diet.

Sugary drinks include soda, sweetened iced tea, sports drinks, fruit punch, and other fruit flavored drinks. (One drink equals 12-ounces.) Diet soda, sugar free drinks, 100% juice, and seltzer are not included.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Diet soda, sugar free drinks, 100% juice, and seltzer are not included.
