Measures.MeasureName: Deaths from PM2.5, Estimated annual rate (age 30+)
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated annual number of all-cause deaths associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the chronic all-cause mortality risk estimate from a comprehensive study by Krewski et al 2009. The rate is the number of deaths attributable to PM2.5 among residents (30 years and older), divided by the population of residents (30 years and older) expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: USEPA Air Quality System; Krewski D, et al. (2009) HEI Research Report 140. Health Effects Institute, Boston, MA; New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; United States Census

Measures.MeasureName: Deaths from PM2.5, Estimated annual number (age 30+)
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated annual number of all-cause deaths associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the chronic all-cause mortality risk estimate from a comprehensive study by Krewski et al 2009.
Measures.Sources: USEPA Air Quality System; Krewski D, et al. (2009) HEI Research Report 140. Health Effects Institute, Boston, MA; New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; United States Census

IndicatorDescription: Traffic density is a measure of the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

Measures.how_calculated: The average number of vehicles traveling on a road segment on any given day during the year was estimated for each segment in a geography. The number of vehicles was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The daily vehicle-miles measures were summed across all segments in a geography and then multiplied by 365 to arrive at an annual measure. Vehicle-miles are expressed in millions per square mile.
Measures.Sources: New York Metropolitan Transportation Council Best Practice Model

IndicatorDescription: Traffic density is a measure of the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

Measures.how_calculated: The average number of cars traveling on a road segment on any given day during the year was estimated for each segment in a geography. The number of cars was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The daily vehicle-miles measures were summed across all segments in a geography and then multiplied by 365 to arrive at an annual measure. Vehicle-miles are expressed in millions per square mile.
Measures.Sources: New York Metropolitan Transportation Council Best Practice Model

IndicatorDescription: Traffic density is a measure of the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

The number of trucks was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The daily vehicle-miles measures were summed across all segments in a geography and then multiplied by 365 to arrive at an annual measure. Vehicle-miles are expressed in millions per square mile.
Measures.Sources: New York Metropolitan Transportation Council Best Practice Model

IndicatorName: Asthma emergency department visits due to PM2.5
IndicatorLabel: Asthma emergency department visits due to PM2.5
IndicatorDescription: PM2.5 can cause asthma ED visits, which represent part of the health burden of fine particle air pollution.

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 asthma ED visits, Estimated annual rate (under age 18)
Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of emergency department (ED) visits for asthma associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of emergency department visits for asthma from the Ito K et al 2007 study conducted on NYC residents. Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents under 18 years of age.
Measures.Sources: USEPA Air Quality System; Ito K et al. (2007) J Expo Sci Environ Epidemiol 17:S45-S60; New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census

IndicatorDescription: Estimating hospitalizations that can be linked to PM2.5 is a way to understand how air pollution impacts public health.

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 health burden (lungs), Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for respiratory causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalizations for all respiratory causes from the Moolgavkar 2000 study conducted on Los Angeles residents between 20-64 years of age and the Zanobetti et al 2009 study in 26 US communities of residents over 65 years of age. Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents over 20 years of Age.
Measures.Sources: USEPA Air Quality System; Moolgavkar SH (2000) Inhal Toxicol 12(Supp 4):75-90; Zanobetti etal.(2009) Environ Hlth 8:58. doi:10.1186/1476-069X-8-58; New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 health burden (lungs), Estimated annual number

IndicatorDescription: PM2.5 can cause cardiovascular hospitalizations, which represent part of the health burden of fine particle air pollution.

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 health burden (heart), Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for cardiovascular causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to natural background (modeled air quality levels under no man-made air pollution emissions). Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalizations for all cardiovascular causes from the Ito K et al 2010 study conducted on New York City residents above 40 years of age. Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents over 40 years of age.
Measures.Sources: US EPA Air Quality System; Ito K et al (2011) Environ Hlth Persp, 119(4):467-473; New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census

Measures.MeasureName: PM2.5 health burden (heart), Estimated annual number

IndicatorName: Cardiac and respiratory deaths due to Ozone
IndicatorLabel: Cardiac and respiratory deaths due to Ozone
IndicatorDescription: Estimating heart and respiratory deaths that can be linked to ozone is a way to understand how air pollution increases mortality.

Measures.MeasureName: Deaths from ozone, Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of cardiovascular and respiratory mortalities associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute cardiorespiratory mortality risk estimate from Huang et al 2005 estimate of New York City risk. Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: USEPA Air Quality System; Huang Y et al. (2005) Environmetrics 16:547-562; New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; United States Census

Measures.MeasureName: Deaths from ozone, Estimated annual number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimate is based on the number of cardiovascular and respiratory mortalities associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Measures.Sources: USEPA Air Quality System; Huang Y et al. (2005) Environmetrics 16:547-562; New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; United States Census

IndicatorDescription: Health insurance coverage is associated with numerous beneficial health effects. Those with health insurance are more likely to have a regular doctor, receive preventive care services, better manage chronic health conditions, have longer life expectancy, and more.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having any kind of health insurance coverage, including private health insurance, prepaid plans such as H-M-Os or government plans such as Medicare or Medicaid, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having any kind of health insurance coverage, including private health insurance, prepaid plans such as H-M-Os or government plans such as Medicare or Medicaid; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: This score summarizes features that promote walking, including density of residences, intersections, subway stops, and retail area. Higher scores indicate greater walkability. Neighborhoods range from -4.0 to 9.4, with zero as an approximate NYC average. This indicator excludes some factors that may impact access and walkability, like maintenance, ADA access, neighborhood safety, and street trees.

Measures.how_calculated: Z-scores were calculated and summed across indicators of residential population density (density of population per total residential land area); intersection density; an entropy measure of land use based on the distribution of building floor area among 5 land-use types (education, entertainment, residential (single- and multi-family), retail, and office); the ratio of retail building floor area to retail land area; and subway stop density. This scale is a variation of Frank's Walkability Index.
Measures.Sources: The Built Environment & Health Project (BEH), Columbia University

IndicatorLabel: Fall-related emergency department visits among older adults
IndicatorDescription: Falls are a leading cause of injury among older adults.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC emergency department visits related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018.

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ; NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.

IndicatorDescription: Falls are a leading cause of injury among older adults.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018.

Measures.how_calculated: Age-specific rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older. Numerator consists of NYC hospital admissions related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) inpatient data, 2016, updated January 2018. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016, updated September 2017.

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ; NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.

IndicatorDescription: Surface temperatures vary based on vegetative cover (which promotes cooling), as well as by materials that retain heat (like paved roads, sidewalks, and buildings). Hotter neighborhoods tend to have more heat-exacerbated deaths associated with extreme heat events.

Measures.how_calculated: Daytime landsat thermal data on surface, July 17, 2018, averaged spatially.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Geological Survey

IndicatorDescription: Vegetative cover is the land covered by trees, grass, or other plants instead of a hard surface like roads, sidewalks, or buildings. Vegetative cover tends to reduce temperatures in the immediate area and may increase air quality.

Measures.how_calculated: Spatial information classifying ground cover is used to calculate a percentage of each geographic area that is covered in vegetation. See this paper for classification methods discussion.
Measures.Sources: University of Vermont remote sensing LiDAR data, assessed using methodology described in: MacFaden, S.W., O'Neil-Dunne, J.P.M., Royer, A.R., Lu, J.W.T., & Rundle, A.G. (2012). High-resolution tree canopy mapping for New York City using LiDAR and object-based image analysis. Journal of Applied Remote Sensing, 6(1).

IndicatorDescription: People with disabilities or access or functional needs may need additional support during extreme weather. For example, they may need extra planning for safe travel out of evacuation zones during a hurricane, or back-up electricity to support medical equipment during power outages. Information provided here about adults with independent living difficulties can help emergency management professionals better prepare our residents for emergencies.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in the civilian noninstitutionalized population (18 years and older) who report independent living difficulty because of a physical, mental, or emotional problem, or having difficulty doing errands alone such as visiting a doctor's office or shopping, divided by the total civilian noninstitutionalized population (18 years and older); expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in the civilian noninstitutionalized population (18 years and older) who report independent living difficulty because of a physical, mental, or emotional problem, or having difficulty doing errands alone such as visiting a doctor's office or shopping.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: Older adults are more vulnerable to extreme weather. Those living alone may have more difficulty getting resources they need in an emergency, and are at higher risk of weather-related illnesses like heat stroke and hypothermia.

Measures.how_calculated: Percent of people aged 65 and older living alone
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of people aged 65 and older living alone.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: Having a regular doctor makes it easier to maintain good health.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults (aged 18 and over) who reported having a personal doctor or health care provider rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having a personal doctor or health care provider, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Older adults (over 65) are more vulnerable to hot weather and heat stress. Air conditioning reduces the risk of heat stroke and other heat-related illness.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults age 65 years or older who reported having a functioning air conditioner in any room in their home, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults age 65 years or older who reported having a functioning air conditioner in any room in their home, divided by the number of adults aged 65 years or older in the area; expressed as percent
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Tree canopy coverage is the percent of a neighborhood that is shaded by trees. Tree shade can lower a neighborhood's temperatures, can make it more comfortable and attractive to walk and stay active.

Measures.how_calculated: Tree canopy cover represents a 'top down' mapping perspective in which tree canopy over-hanging city features (such as sidewalks) is measured. The percent is calculated by dividing the area of tree canopy in km2 within the UHF neighborhood by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies).
Measures.Sources: The Built Environment & Health Project (BEH), Columbia University

IndicatorDescription: Neighborhoods with greater subway access encourage active transportation, which may increase physical activity and overall health of residents. They also tend to have more foot traffic, which attracts businesses and can foster community.

Measures.how_calculated: Subway station density measure takes into account multiple route-transfer opportunities at one subway station and each stop is counted only once regardless of how many route-transfer opportunities are available at any given subway station. Density is calculated by dividing the count of MTA subways stations as of 2012 by the total land area in km2 of the UHF neighborhood (excluding inland water bodies).
Measures.Sources: The Built Environment & Health Project (BEH), Columbia University

IndicatorDescription: Carbon monoxide detectors are required in NYC homes by law. Failure to provide or maintain a detector can put people at risk for carbon monoxide poisoning and death.

Measures.how_calculated: A 3-year Average annual number of carbon monoxide incidents where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene, and there was no detector (alarm) or alarm did not go off.
Measures.Sources: Fire Department of New York City (FDNY) Carbon Monoxide Incidents

Measures.how_calculated: A 3-year Average annual rate of carbon monoxide incidents where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene, and there was no detector (alarm) or alarm did not go off; expressed as incidents per 10,000 buildings.
Measures.Sources: Fire Department of New York City (FDNY) Carbon Monoxide Incidents

IndicatorDescription: Diabetes is a metabolic disorder that affects how well your body can get energy from food and drink. Adults can be born with diabetes or develop it later in life. Health problems from diabetes can include heart disease, stroke, vision problems, and amputations.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who have ever been told by a doctor, nurse or other health professional that they have diabetes, divided by all adults and adjusted for age; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who have ever been told by a doctor, nurse or other health professional that they have diabetes rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who have ever been told by a doctor, nurse or other health professional that they have diabetes, divided by all adults; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Adults reporting walking for transportation in the last 7 days (from when they were surveyed)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having walked at least 10 minutes to get to and from places, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having walked at least 10 minutes to get to and from places, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Adults reporting biking for transportation in the last 7 days (from when they were surveyed).

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having biked to get to and from places, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having biked to get to and from places, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Hospitalizations for cold-related illnesses, such as hypothermia and frostbite, represent part of the public health burden of cold weather. Cold weather can also make chronic conditions worse.

Measures.how_calculated: NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

Measures.how_calculated: NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Note: Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated: NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

Measures.MeasureName: Cold ED visits, Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). IndicatorLabel: Children under 5 years old in Poverty
IndicatorDescription: Poverty is a major determinant of health, since poverty deprives people of access to health and safety resources.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children who live in a household for whom poverty status is determined, whose annual income falls below twice the federal poverty.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children in a household whose annual income falls below twice the federal poverty level, divided by the number of children in households for whom poverty status is determined; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked citywide in 3 groups (tertiles), so that neighborhoods can be grouped and compared.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorName: Renter-occupied homes with no housing problems
IndicatorLabel: Renter-occupied homes with no housing problems
IndicatorDescription: Healthy homes are free of housing problems.

Measures.MeasureName: Renter-occupied homes with no housing problems, Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households reporting no maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8.5 x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit).
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.MeasureName: Renter-occupied homes with no housing problems, Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households in an area reporting no maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8.5 x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit), divided by the number of renter-occupied households in the area; expressed as percent..
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorDescription: Sidewalks are important for commuting, businesses, and physical activity. Greater sidewalk area can contribute to a safer pedestrian environment, support vibrant business districts and can foster social interaction among residents.

Measures.how_calculated: The total curb-to-building sidewalk area in square kilometers within the UHF neighborhood divided by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies).
Measures.Sources: The Built Environment & Health Project (BEH), Columbia University

IndicatorDescription: Elevated blood lead levels are 5+ mcg/dL. There is no safe level of lead in the blood. Lead poisoning can cause learning and behavior problems, and delay growth and mental development.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 5 mcg/dL or greater. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child's blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the number of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above a certain level reported by the Health Department in other publications.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 10 mcg/dL or greater. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child's blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the number of children newly identified with blood lead levels of 10 mcg/dL or greater reported by the Health Department in other publications.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 15 mcg/dL or greater. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child's blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the number of children newly identified with blood lead levels of 15 mcg/dL or greater reported by the Health Department in other publications.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 5 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the total number of children less than 6 years old who were tested for lead poisoning in a given year; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child's blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the rate of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above a certain level reported by the Health Department in other publications.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 10 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the number of children less than 6 years old who were tested for lead poisoning in a given year; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child's blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the rate of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above 10 mcg/dL reported by the Health Department in other publications.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 15 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the number of children less than 6 years old who were tested for lead poisoning in a given year; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child's blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the rate of children newly identified with blood lead levels of 15 mcg/dL or greater reported by the Health Department in other publications.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Children under 6 years of age tested for lead poisoning in a given year. Children may be tested multiple times in a given year but are only counted once. All children are counted regardless of blood specimen type (confirmed or unconfirmed); the number is rounded to the nearest 100.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 3.5 mcg/dL or greater. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child's blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the number of children newly identified with blood lead levels of 3.5 mcg/dL or greater reported by the Health Department in other publications.

Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 3.5 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the number of children less than 6 years old who were tested for lead poisoning in a given year; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child's blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the rate of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above 3.5 mcg/dL reported by the Health Department in other publications.

IndicatorDescription: Air conditioning is an important way to avoid heat stress, especially for persons with limited mobility.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area reporting having functioning air conditioning, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households reporting having functioning air conditioning
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area reporting not having functioning air conditioning, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorName: Homes with grab bars in bathroom (among older adult households)
IndicatorLabel: Homes with grab bars in bathroom (among older adult households)
IndicatorDescription: Grab bars in bathrooms can help prevent falls among older adults.

Measures.MeasureName: Homes with grab bars in bathroom (among older adult households), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of homes with grab bars in the bathroom, among homes with adults aged 65 years or older.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.MeasureName: Homes with grab bars in bathroom (among older adult households), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of homes with grab bars in the bathroom, among homes with adults aged 65 years or older, divided by the estimated number of households with adults aged 65 years or older; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorDescription: In New York State, all children must be tested for lead before age 3. There is no safe level of lead in the blood.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children born in New York City to New York City resident mothers tested for lead poisoning before the age of three years. To identify children tested for lead poisoning, birth records for all children born in a given year in New York City to New York City resident mothers were matched to children tested for lead poisoning in the New York City Childhood Lead Registry.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.how_calculated: Number of children born in New York City to New York City resident mothers who were tested for lead poisoning before the age of three years, divided by the number of children born in New York City to New York City resident mothers turning three years old; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; New York City Healthy Homes Program

IndicatorDescription: The HVI shows the risk of community-level heat impacts, like deaths, due to extreme heat events. It is made up of data on surface temperature, green space, air conditioning access, median income, and Black population (the population most excluded from heat resources). Differences in community-level heat impacts stem from structural racism, which limits access to preventive resources. See our interactive Heat Vulnerability Index

Measures.how_calculated: Each neighborhood receives a score from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk) based on a statistical model that uses social and environmental factors to estimate risk of heat-related death across NYC neighborhoods. A low vulnerability score does not mean no risk. Every neighborhood has residents at risk for heat illness and death. Residents who are at highest heat risk are those who do not have or use air conditioning and are older or have chronic health conditions or serious mental illnesses.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey 5 year estimates, 2016-2020; LiDAR, 2017, NYC Office of Information Technology; US Census, 2020; ECOSSTRESS thermal imaging, August 27, 2020, NASA; United States Census Housing and Vacancy Survey, 2017

IndicatorDescription: Disinfection by-products are chemicals that can form when a disinfectant such as chlorine reacts with naturally occurring organic matter and other substances in the source water. Current research is investigating whether there are health effects from chronic exposure to the by-products of water disinfection.

Measures.MeasureName: Disinfection by-products (TTHM), Qtr maximum allowable contaminant level (MCL)
Measures.how_calculated: The highest level of TTHM that is allowed in drinking water according to regulatory standards
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over each quarter.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each quarter.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.MeasureName: Disinfection by-products (TTHM), Maximum allowable contaminant level (MCL)
Measures.how_calculated: The highest level of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) that is allowed in drinking water according to regulatory standards.
Measures.Sources: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each year.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The number of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) samples taken throughout the distribution system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

Measures.how_calculated: The number of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) samples taken throughout the distribution system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Safe Drinking Water Information System

IndicatorDescription: Asbestos is a naturally-occurring mineral which was commonly used as an insulation material until the 1970s. Inhaling high concentrations of asbestos fibers over a long time can produce lung inflammation and scarring resulting in the chronic lung disease called asbestosis, a type of pneumoconiosis. New York City construction, insulation, and shipyard workers who installed, disturbed, or removed asbestos without respiratory protection are at risk. Additionally, smokers who are exposed to asbestos have a greater risk of developing asbestos-related diseases than non-smokers. Typically it takes more than ten years from the time of exposure before symptoms develop. The use of proper protective masks is key to preventing the disease, since there is no treatment.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations with an asbestosis ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 501, among NYC residents aged 15 years or older, over a three-year period, divided by the population of NYC residents aged 15 years or older, expressed as 3-year Average annual rate per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System; U.S. Census Bureau Population Estimates (V2016)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations with an asbestosis ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 501, among NYC residents aged 15 years or older, over a 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorDescription: In New York City, the most common cause of lead poisoning in non-pregnant adults is from working in the construction. Workers are exposed by breathing or ingesting lead dust or fumes during work that disturbs old lead based paint. Workers in other industries, as well as hobbyists, may be at risk if they work with lead-containing metal, paint, pigments, ceramic glazes or bullets. Adults can also be exposed to lead through lead-contaminated products, like some imported health remedies, spices, foods, pottery and cosmetics.

Measures.MeasureName: Elevated blood lead levels (age 16+), Number (10+ mcg/dL)
Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years or older with blood lead levels (BLL) greater than or equal to 10 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Heavy Metal Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Elevated blood lead levels (age 16+), Average annual rate (25+ mcg/dL)
Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years and older with blood lead levels greater than or equal to 25 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period, divided by the employed NYC population aged 16 years or older in each of the 3 years, expressed as 3-year Average annual rate per 100,000 employed persons.
Measures.Sources: New York State Heavy Metal Registry; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

Measures.MeasureName: Elevated blood lead levels (age 16+), Number (25+ mcg/dL)
Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years or older with blood lead levels greater than or equal to 25 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: New York State Heavy Metal Registry

Measures.MeasureName: Elevated blood lead levels (age 16+), Average annual rate (10+ mcg/dL)
Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years and older with blood lead levels greater than or equal to 10 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period, divided by the employed NYC population aged 16 years or older in each of the 3 years, expressed as 3-year Average annual rate per 100,000 employed persons.
Measures.Sources: New York State Heavy Metal Registry; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

IndicatorDescription: Pneumoconiosis is a general term given to any lung disease caused by breathing in certain particles or fibers over a prolonged period. Pneumoconiosis usually results from a workplace exposure. The most common causes of pneumoconiosis include asbestos fibers, silica dust, and coal dust. There is no cure, but it can be prevented with appropriate respiratory protection.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations with a pneumoconiosis ICD-9-CM diagnosis code 500 - 505 or an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code J60 - J64, among NYC residents aged 15 years or older, divided by the population of NYC residents aged 15 years or older, expressed as 3-year Average annual rate per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System; U.S. Census Bureau Population Estimates (V2016)

Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations with a pneumoconiosis ICD-9-CM diagnosis code 500 - 505 or an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code J60 - J64, among NYC residents aged 15 years or older, over a 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorDescription: Workers' compensation is a type of insurance that provides medical care for workers who are injured or become ill as a direct result of their job. Hospitalizations billed to workers' comp represent only a portion of work-related injuries that require hospital care. It is important to realize that workers' compensation policies vary from state-to-state with respect to the types of workers covered and the types of injuries and illnesses eligible for compensation

Measures.MeasureName: Hospitalizations billed to workers' compensation, Average annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations among employed NYC residents aged 16 years or older with workers' compensation listed as the primary payer over a 3-year period, divided by the population of employed NYC residents aged 16 years or older in each of these years, expressed as a 3-year Average annual rate per 100,000.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey; Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

Measures.MeasureName: Hospitalizations billed to workers' compensation, Number (employed)
Measures.how_calculated: Number of hospitalizations among employed NYC residents aged 16 years or older with workers' compensation listed as the primary payer in hospital discharge data over a 3-year period.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorDescription: Fatal work-related injuries include deaths resulting from unintentional injuries such as falls, acute poisonings, and motor vehicle crashes that occur during travel for work, and intentional injuries (i.e., homicides and suicides) that occur at work. Fatal injuries that occur during a commute are not included.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fatal work-related injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries. CFOI produces statistics on fatal work-related injuries by cross-referencing multiple sources, such as death certificates, workers' compensation reports, and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) investigation reports.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries

Measures.MeasureName: Work-related deaths (all industries), Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of fatal work-related injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, divided by the size of the NYC workforce, expressed as deaths per 10,000 workers.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

IndicatorDescription: Construction is the most dangerous industry in NYC, with nearly a third of work-related injury deaths each year. Falls from scaffolds, ladders and roofs are the most common cause of fatal injuries among construction workers.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of fatal construction injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries

Measures.MeasureName: Work-related deaths (construction industry), Citywide, Annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of fatal construction injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, divided by the NYC construction workforce, expressed as deaths per 10,000 workers.
Measures.Sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey

IndicatorName: Elevated blood lead levels (under age 6), by NTA
IndicatorLabel: Elevated blood lead levels (under age 6), by NTA
IndicatorDescription: Elevated blood lead levels are 5+ mcg/dL. There is no safe level of lead in the blood. Lead poisoning can cause learning and behavior problems, and delay growth and mental development.

Measures.MeasureName: Child lead poisoning, by NTA, Average Annual Number BLL >=5 g/dL
Measures.how_calculated:
Sum of the number of children under 6 years of age with blood lead levels (BLL) 5 mcg/dL or greater over the time period, divided by the number of years in the time period. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, for this measure children are only counted once per year using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.

  • For the purpose of providing data for small geographic areas, multiple years of data were combined to get sufficient numbers of observations to make more reliable estimates for a greater number of neighborhood tabulation areas (NTAs).
  • Annual numbers and rates of children under 6 years of age with elevated blood lead levels at the citywide, borough, and United Hospital Fund neighborhood level are available here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.MeasureName: Child lead poisoning, by NTA, Average Annual Number Tested
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of children under 6 years of age tested for lead poisoning. Children may be tested multiple times in a given year but for this measure are only counted once per year. All children are counted regardless of blood specimen type (confirmed or unconfirmed). Numbers are rounded to nearest 10. Read more about definitions and measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

Measures.MeasureName: Child lead poisoning, by NTA, Rate (5+ mcg/dL)
Measures.how_calculated:
Number of children under 6 years of age tested with blood lead levels (BLL) 5 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the total number of children under 6 years of age who were tested; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, for this measure children are only counted once per year using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.

  • For the purpose of providing data for small geographic areas, multiple years of data were combined to get sufficient numbers of observations to make more reliable estimates for a greater number of neighborhood tabulation areas (NTAs). 
  • Annual numbers and rates of children under 6 years of age with elevated blood lead levels at the citywide, borough, and United Hospital Fund neighborhood level are available here.
Measures.Sources: New York City Healthy Homes Program

IndicatorDescription: Babesiosis is a rare, sometimes severe or fatal tick-borne disease caused by a parasite that infects red blood cells. Babesiosis is transmitted by the bite of an infected blacklegged tick (the same tick that transmits Lyme disease and anaplasmosis). Most patients acquire this disease while traveling outside NYC. However, there has been an increase in the number of cases with no history of travel to endemic areas, primarily in Staten Island, as well as isolated cases in the Bronx and Queens. Babesiosis can also be transmitted through transfused blood products.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of cases meeting the national case definition.
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population using NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal estimates, updated April 2017.
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

Measures.how_calculated: Crude Rate per 100,000 Population
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

IndicatorDescription: Adults reporting that their health is excellent, very good, or good.

IndicatorName: Adults reporting personal use of pesticides

IndicatorDescription: Each component of the criminal justice continuum - from arrest to re-entry - carries various health consequences, and a growing body of literature has documented severe adverse health outcomes associated with incarceration on the individual, their families, and neighborhoods.

Measures.how_calculated: Crude rate of of incarcerated adults in NYC Department of Correction facilities per 1,000 population ages 18 and older. Addresses at admission to New York City Department of Correction facilities were geocoded; 69% of all records could be geocoded to a valid NTA. Data were limited to those ages 18 years of age and older and deduplicated by individuals' unique ID numbers and NTAs of residence. The six years of count data were annualized by dividing by six.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Correction

IndicatorDescription: The rate of people who die before age 65 can indicate the overall health of a population.

IndicatorDescription: Students missing 20 or more school days per year.

IndicatorDescription: Adults age 16+ who are unemployed.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of people in the civilian labor force (16 years and older) who are unemployed. All civilians 16 years old and over are classified as unemployed if they (1) were neither "at work" nor "with a job but not at work" during the reference week, and (2) were looking for work during the last 4 weeks, and (3) were available to accept a job. Also included as unemployed are civilians who did not work at all during the reference week, were waiting to be called back to a job from which they had been laid off, and were available for work except for temporary illness.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of people in the civilian labor force (16 years and older) who are unemployed, divided by the total civilian labor force; expressed as percent.All civilians 16 years old and over are classified as unemployed if they (1) were neither "at work" nor "with a job but not at work" during the reference week, and (2) were looking for work during the last 4 weeks, and (3) were available to accept a job. Also included as unemployed are civilians who did not work at all during the reference week, were waiting to be called back to a job from which they had been laid off, and were available for work except for temporary illness.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey

IndicatorDescription: West Nile virus is transmitted through the bite of infected mosquitoes. While most people who are infected will not go on to develop symptoms, about 20% experience mild or moderate illness and more rarely, neuroinvasive disease which can present as encephalitis or meningitis. Most of the West Nile disease cases detected by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene represent neuroinvasive disease as these patients are more likely to seek care.

IndicatorDescription: Eviction often leads to residential instability, moving into poor quality housing, overcrowding, and homelessness, all of which is associated with negative health among adults and children.People who are threatened with eviction, even before they lose their home, are more likely to report poor health, high blood pressure, depression (from "The Hidden Health Crisis of Eviction" by Allison Bovell-Ammo and Megan Sandel).

IndicatorDescription: Non-fatal, violence-related injuries that result in hospitalizations. These are more common than homicides and help paint the larger picture of the burden of violence on communities.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only. Counts are the number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only. Counts are summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorDescription: Deaths due to cold weather represent part of the public health burden of cold weather. Cold weather can also worsen chronic conditions, sometimes leading to death. This data only includes deaths directly attributed to cold on death certificates.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths during cold season months of October-April with an underlying or contributing cause that includes excessive natural cold (ICD10 code X31), hypothermia and other effects of reduced temperature (ICD10 codes T68-69), and frostbite (T33-34) among NYC residents. Number excludes deaths due to excessive cold of man-made origin (ICD10 code W93) and intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X6-X9, Y0, Y35, Y36).
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorDescription: People who use electric medical equipment are more vulnerable during power outages or evacuations.

Measures.MeasureName: Households using electric medical equipment, Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households reporting someone using electric medical equipment, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.MeasureName: Households using electric medical equipment, Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households reporting someone using electric medical equipment; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorName: Asthma emergency department visits (age 4 and under), by NTA
IndicatorDescription: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Things like smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander can trigger asthma.

Measures.MeasureName: Asthma ED visits (age 4 and under), by NTA, Average annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Average annual number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasureName: Asthma ED visits (age 4 and under), by NTA, Number
Measures.how_calculated: Aggregated number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorDescription: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Things like smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander can trigger asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years. ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasureName: Asthma ED visits (age 5 to 17), Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 17 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

IndicatorDescription: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Things like smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander can trigger asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older). ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown for adults, because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasureName: Asthma ED visits (adults), Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older), divided by the population of adults (18 years and older) using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown for adults, because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated: Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older), divided by the population in 5 year age groups, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown for adults, because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data
