IndicatorDescription: The percentage of the population who live within walking distance to a park: a quarter-mile or less to entrances of smaller sites, such as sitting areas and playgrounds, and half-mile or less to entrances of larger parks. Increased access to green space and open space can contribute to increased levels of physical activity.

Measures.how_calculated: A map of "walk-to-a-park service areas" from the NYC Parks Department was overlayed onto a map of 2017 population estimates by census tract to calculate the percentage of the population that potentially live within the service area. These percentages were aggregated up to a neighborhood level.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Parks and Recreation; New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates

IndicatorDescription: A neighborhood's ratio of bodegas to supermarkets can indicate whether the environment makes accessing unhealthy food easier for residents, as bodegas are less likely to have healthy food options than supermarkets.

Measures.how_calculated: The number of bodegas per supermarket within an area based on address of business. Bodegas are defined as food purchasing establishments with less than 4,000 square foot and excludes specialty stores, such as bakeries and vitamin stores. Supermarkets are defined as retail food purchasing establishments with greater than or equal to 10,000 square feet or have a chain supermarket name regardless of size.
Measures.Sources: NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets

IndicatorDescription: Bike lanes can improve bicyclist and pedestrian safety, physical activity, and sustainable transportation use. An increase in percentage of streets with bike lanes can indicate a safer cycling environment in a neighborhood which may increase overall cycling.

Measures.how_calculated: Percentage of street mileage with conventional and protected bicycle lanes, not including sharrows, dirt trails, boardwalks, and velodromes.
Measures.Sources: New York City Department of Transportation

IndicatorName: Walking distance to a subway station
IndicatorDescription: The percentage of population within a quarter-mile of a subway station entrance. When more people have convenient access to the transit system, they're more likely to use it. Subway access encourages active transportation, which improves the health of residents.

Measures.how_calculated: Walking distance to a subway station is defined as 1/4-mile or less. Distance was measured between the centroid of 2010 Census blocks and the nearest station entrance. Census block populations within areas defined as walking distance were summed across the neighborhood and divided by total neighborhood population.
Measures.Sources: United States Census; Metropolitan Transportation Authority

IndicatorDescription: Children ages 1 to 13 that have ever received an asthma diagnosis.

Measures.MeasureName: Children ever diagnosed with asthma, Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 1-13 years who were ever diagnosed with asthma, divided by all children of the same ages, expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.MeasureName: Children ever diagnosed with asthma, Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 1-13 years who were ever diagnosed with asthma.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorDescription: The saliva, feces, and shedding body parts of cockroaches are an allergen and can trigger asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home reporting cockroaches in the past 90 days, divided by the number of children in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home reporting cockroaches in the past 90 days
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorDescription: The presence of mice or rats in the home is often associated with poor housing maintenance. These pests can contaminate food and worsen asthma.

Measures.MeasureName: Children in homes with mice (age 1-13), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home with signs of mice in the past 90 days.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.MeasureName: Children in homes with mice (age 1-13), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home with signs of mice in the past 90 days, divided by the number of children in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorName: Children in homes with cracks or holes (age 1-13)
IndicatorLabel: Children in homes with cracks or holes (age 1-13)
IndicatorDescription: Cracks or holes are a maintenance deficiency linked to the presence of mice, rats, and cockroaches. Pests in the home can contaminate food and worsen asthma.

Measures.MeasureName: Children in homes with cracks or holes (age 1-13), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in homes with cracks or holes in the walls, ceiling or floors.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.MeasureName: Children in homes with cracks or holes (age 1-13), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in homes with cracks or holes in the walls, ceiling or floors, divided by the number of children in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorName: Children in homes with supplemental heat (age 13 and under)
IndicatorLabel: Children in homes with supplemental heat (age 13 and under)
IndicatorDescription: The need for supplemental heat may mean a building's main heat source doesn't work - and can indicate the presence of other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies, which can harm children's health.

Measures.MeasureName: Children in homes with supplemental heat (age 13 and under), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home that used supplemental heat during the winter.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.MeasureName: Children in homes with supplemental heat (age 13 and under), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 0-13 years living in a home that used supplemental heat during the winter, divided by the number of children in the area; expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorDescription: A death due to carbon monoxide may be fire-related or non-fire-related.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths with an underlying or contributing cause that includes the toxic effect of carbon monoxide (ICD10 code T58) and accidental injury/poisoning due to fire and flames (ICD10 codes X00-X09) among NYC residents. Excludes intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X60-Y09, Y35-36).
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths with an underlying or contributing cause that includes the toxic effect of carbon monoxide (ICD10 code T58) and unintentional non-fire poisoning (ICD10 code X47) among NYC residents. Excludes intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X60-Y09, Y35-36).
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of deaths with an underlying or contributing cause that includes the toxic effect of carbon monoxide (ICD10 code T58) among NYC residents that are neither fire-related or non-fire-related, or have codes indicating both fire- and non-fire related causes. Excludes intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X60-Y09, Y35-36).
Measures.Sources: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

IndicatorName: Renter-occupied homes with any health-related housing problems
IndicatorLabel: Renter-occupied homes with any health-related housing problems
IndicatorDescription: Homes with housing problems can threaten the health of the people who live there.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households reporting any health-related maintenance problems (cockroaches, mice or rats in the building, cracks or holes in walls, ceilings or floors, leaks from outside, toilet breakdowns, lack of air conditioning, heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, or broken plaster or peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches).
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households reporting any health-related maintenance problems (cockroaches, mice or rats in the building, cracks or holes in walls, ceilings or floors, leaks from outside, toilet breakdowns, lack of air conditioning, heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, or broken plaster or peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches),divided by the number of renter-occupied households in the area; expressed as percent..
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorDescription: Non-fatal, violence-related injuries that result in emergency department visits. These are more common than homicides and help paint the larger picture of the burden of violence on communities.

Measures.MeasureName: Violence-related ED visits (all ages), Age-adjusted rate
Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC nonfatal assault emergency department visits among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only. Counts are the number of NYC nonfatal assault emergency department visits among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only. Counts are summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC nonfatal assault emergency department visits among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

IndicatorDescription: Households that postponed health care in the last 12 months

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that postponed health care for financial reasons, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Health care includes dental, preventive care or check-up, mental health, treatment or diagnosis of illness or health condition, and prescription drugs.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that postponed health care for financial reasons, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Health care includes dental, preventive care or check-up, mental health, treatment or diagnosis of illness or health condition, and prescription drugs; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorLabel: Homes with reported falls among adults 65 and older
IndicatorDescription: Falls are a leading cause of injury among older adults.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported anyone 65 or older having fallen in the home.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of households that reported anyone 65 or older having fallen in the home, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (NYCHVS)

IndicatorLabel: Children exposed to tobacco smoke in home (ages 1-13 years)
IndicatorDescription: The number of children aged 1-13 years exposed to tobacco smoke at home all of the time, most of the time, or occasionally. Secondhand smoke is harmful to children and can cause or worsen respiratory and asthma issues and ear infections.

Measures.MeasureName: Secondhand smoke exposure at home (children), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children aged 1-13 years living in a home reporting cigarette, cigar, or other tobacco smoking all of the time, most of the time, or occasionally.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.MeasureName: Secondhand smoke exposure at home (children), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children aged 1-13 years living in a home reporting cigarette, cigar, or other tobacco smoking all of the time, most of the time, or occasionally, divided by the number of children in the area as per the 2015-19 American Community Survey, expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorDescription: Carbon monoxide (CO) exposure can be life-threatening or fatal. ED visits and hospitalizations allows us to understand the burden of CO-related health impacts.

Measures.MeasureName: Carbon monoxide emergency department visits, Number (fire-related)
Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 for carbon monoxide poisoning and any unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code of T58 for accidental or undetermined-cause carbon monoxide poisoning and any fire-related code within the range of X00-X08. For all years, excludes records with intentional injury codes. Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. Also, data from 2015 prior to the transition are not directly comparable to data from 2015 after the transition due to differing case definitions.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasureName: Carbon monoxide emergency department visits, Rate (fire-related)
Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 for carbon monoxide poisoning and any unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code of T58 for accidental or undetermined-cause carbon monoxide poisoning and any fire-related code within the range of X00-X08. For all years, excludes records with intentional injury codes. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. Also, data from 2015 prior to the transition are not directly comparable to data from 2015 after the transition due to differing case definitions.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates

Measures.MeasureName: Carbon monoxide emergency department visits, Number (not fire-related)
Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 for carbon monoxide poisoning and any of the following codes: E818, E825, E838, E844, E867, E868.0-1, E869.9, or having E868.2- E868.9 codes (regardless of the presence or absence of 986). After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM codes of T58.01, T58.11, T58.2X1, T58.8X1, or T58.91. For all years, excludes records with intentional or fire-related injury codes. Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. Also, data from 2015 prior to the transition are not directly comparable to data from 2015 after the transition due to differing case definitions.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents hospitalized. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 for carbon monoxide poisoning and any unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code of T58 for accidental or undetermined-cause carbon monoxide poisoning and any fire-related code within the range of X00-X08. Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. IndicatorLabel: Home fall-related emergency department visits among older adults
IndicatorDescription: Falls are a leading cause of injury among older adults.

Measures.MeasureName: Home fall ED visits, Age-adjusted rate
Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC ED visits related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. ED visits for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ; NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC ED visitis related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. ED visits for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018.

IndicatorDescription: Heat stress hospitalizations weather are part of the public health burden due to hot weather. Data aggregated over 10 years provides enough stablility to display neighborhood impacts.

Measures.MeasureName: Heat hospitalizations, Average annual age-adjusted rate
Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September summed over a 10-year period for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Numbers are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates. Quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. The Average annual age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases admitted before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates; Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. The numbers are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. IndicatorDescription: The HVI shows the risk of community-level heat impacts, like deaths, due to extreme heat events. It is made up of data on surface temperature, green space, air conditioning access, median income, and Black population (the population most excluded from heat resources). Differences in community-level heat impacts stem from structural racism, which limits access to preventive resources. See our interactive Heat Vulnerability Index

Measures.how_calculated: Each neighborhood receives a score from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk) based on a statistical model that uses social and environmental factors to estimate risk of heat-related death across NYC neighborhoods. A low vulnerability score does not mean no risk. Every neighborhood has residents at risk for heat illness and death. Residents who are at highest heat risk are those who do not have or use air conditioning and are older or have chronic health conditions or serious mental illnesses.
Measures.Sources: American Community Survey 5 year estimates, 2016-2020; LiDAR, 2017, NYC Office of Information Technology; US Census, 2020; ECOSSTRESS thermal imaging, August 27, 2020, NASA; United States Census Housing and Vacancy Survey, 2017

IndicatorDescription: Adults age 18 and older who have ever been diagnosed with asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported still having medically diagnosed asthma, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported still having medically diagnosed asthma, divided by all adults; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported still having medically diagnosed asthma, divided by all adults and adjusted for age; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: Sanitation supports public health by providing clean, healthy public spaces for people to live, work, and get around. Litter baskets, or trash cans, are associated with a decrease in littering. Enclosed, non-wire baskets are generally better than wire baskets.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of DSNY-regulated litter baskets.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Sanitation data, retrieved from NYC Open Data

Measures.how_calculated: Number of DSNY-regulated litter baskets, divided by neighborhood area in square miles.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Sanitation data, retrieved from NYC Open Data

Measures.how_calculated: Number of DSNY-regulated non-wire litter baskets.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Sanitation data, retrieved from NYC Open Data

Measures.how_calculated: Number of DSNY-regulated non-wire litter baskets, divided by neighborhood area in square miles.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Sanitation data, retrieved from NYC Open Data

Measures.how_calculated: Percent of all DSNY-regulated litter baskets in neighborhood that are non-wire baskets.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Sanitation data, retrieved from NYC Open Data

IndicatorDescription: Adults with probable depression in the past 2 weeks (from when they were surveyed). Depression is a common mental health disorder. Symptoms include feeling sad or hopeless, having little interest in doing things and feeling tired.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who were determined to have probable depression in the past 2 weeks based on the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-8) scale, pooled over 2 years, divided by all adults; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who were determined to have probable depression in the past 2 weeks based on the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-8) scale, pooled over 2 years, divided by all adults; expressed as percent.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who were determined to have probable depression in the past 2 weeks based on the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-8) scale, pooled over 2 years, divided by all adults.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: A psychiatric hospitalization is defined as an overnight stay or longer in a psychiatric inpatient unit (excluding emergency room visits without an inpatient admission) for individuals with behaviors or symptoms that are likely to result in harm to themselves or others.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC adults aged 18 years and older who visited an NYC hospital for a mental health related reason in 2019
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS); Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Number of adults aged 18 years and older who visited an NYC hospital for a mental health related reason in 2019, divided by the population of adults (18 years and older) using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) inpatient data 2019, updated January 2022. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2019, updated March 2021.; New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2018, updated September 2019.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of NYC adults aged 18 years and older who visited an NYC hospital for a mental health related reason in 2019, summed within six age groups (18-24, 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) inpatient data 2019, updated January 2022. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2019, updated March 2021.; New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2018, updated September 2019.

IndicatorDescription: Serious psychological distress includes mental health problems that impact social, occupational, and educational functioning.

Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS); Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who were determined to have probable serious psychological distress in the past 30 days based on the Kessler 6 scale, divided by all adults; expressed as percent
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who were determined to have probable serious psychological distress in the past 30 days based on the Kessler 6 scale, divided by all adults and age adjusted, pooled years 2019-2020, expressed as percent
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

IndicatorDescription: An intentional injury death that results from self-harm.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of suicide deaths, pooled years 2015-2019. Suicide deaths are identified using the ICD codes U03, X60-X84, and Y87.0. Note that identified deaths include non-residents who died by suicide in NYC, and does not include NYC residents who died by suicide outside of NYC.
Measures.Sources: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS); Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of suicide deaths in NYC, pooled years 2015-2019, divided by total NYC population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents, pooled years 2015-2019.

Suicide deaths are identified using the ICD codes U03, X60-X84, and Y87.0. Note that identified deaths include non-residents who died by suicide in NYC, and does not include NYC residents who died by suicide outside of NYC.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) inpatient data 2019, updated January 2022. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2019, updated March 2021.; New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2018, updated September 2019.

Measures.how_calculated:
Number of suicide deaths, pooled years 2015-2019, summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64,65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

Suicide deaths are identified using the ICD codes U03, X60-X84, and Y87.0. Note that identified deaths include non-residents who died by suicide in NYC, and does not include NYC residents who died by suicide outside of NYC.
Measures.Sources: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) inpatient data 2019, updated January 2022. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2019, updated March 2021.; New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics. NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2018, updated September 2019.

IndicatorDescription: Retail locations that sell tobacco products. Neighborhoods with higher densities of tobacco retailers increase access to tobacco and may increase smoking rates.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of tobacco retailers holding a DCA license so they can legally operate in NYC, as of 1/20/23.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection accessed via NYC OpenData.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of tobacco retailers holding a DCA license so they can legally operate in NYC, as of 1/20/23, divided by square miles of a given geographical area.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection accessed via NYC OpenData.

IndicatorLabel: Children exposed to e-cigarette smoke in home
IndicatorDescription: E-cigarette smoke: The number of children aged 1-13 years exposed to e-cigarette smoke at home all of the time, most of the time, or occasionally. Chemicals in the vapor from e-cigarettes can be harmful to kids.

Measures.MeasureName: E-cigarette vapor exposure at home (children), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children aged 1-13 years living in a home reporting e-cigarette smoking all of the time, most of the time, or occasionally.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.MeasureName: E-cigarette vapor exposure at home (children), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children aged 1-13 years living in a home reporting e-cigarette smoking all of the time, most of the time, or occasionally, divided by the number of children in the area as per the 2015-19 American Community Survey, expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorDescription: The average number of Citi Bikes available to rent per each area between 7am-7pm. Biking bridges gaps in existing public transportation systems and is a great way to exercise. Neighborhoods with lower Citi Bike availability have limited access to this beneficial public resource.

Measures.how_calculated: Yearly bike availability is calculated by totaling average daily bike availability and dividing by the number of days in the year. Average daily bike availability is calculated from totaling bikes available at every station per each area as reported at every hour mark from 7am to 7pm on a given day and dividing by the number of hours (13). Values are rounded to the nearest whole number after all calculations are complete.
Measures.Sources: Citi Bike GBFS feed

Measures.how_calculated: Yearly bike availability is calculated by totaling average daily bike availability and dividing by the number of days in the year. Average daily bike availability is calculated from totaling bikes available per 1000 people at every station per each area as reported at every hour mark from 7am to 7pm on a given day and dividing by the number of hours (13). Values are rounded to the single decimal place after all calculations are complete.
Measures.Sources: Citi Bike GBFS feed

Measures.MeasureName: Average Citi Bike availability, Bikes per station
Measures.how_calculated: Yearly bike availability is calculated by totaling average daily bike availability and dividing by the number of days in the year. Average daily bike availability is calculated from totaling bikes available at every station per each area as reported at every hour mark from 7am to 7pm on a given day and dividing by the number of hours (13). Values are rounded to the nearest whole number after all calculations and are complete and then divided by the number of stations per area.
Measures.Sources: Citi Bike GBFS feed

IndicatorDescription: Biking bridges gaps in existing public transportation systems and is a great way to exercise. Neighborhoods with fewer Citi Bike stations have limited access to this beneficial public resource. Neighborhoods with relatively few docks per station may also have limited access to bikes even if they have many stations. The National Association of City Transportation Officials (NACTO) suggests that there should be 28 stations per square mile and one station every 1000 feet.

Measures.how_calculated: The number of Citi Bike stations per geographic area.
Measures.Sources: Citi Bike GBFS feed

Measures.how_calculated: The number of Citi Bike stations per geographic area, divided by the area's square mileage.
Measures.Sources: Citi Bike GBFS feed

Measures.MeasureName: Citi Bike stations, Docks per station
Measures.how_calculated: The total dock capacity of Citi Bike stations per geographic area, divided by total stations per area.
Measures.Sources: Citi Bike GBFS feed

Measures.MeasureName: Citi Bike stations, Docks per 1000 people
Measures.how_calculated: The total dock capacity of Citi Bike stations per geographic area, divided by total population per area.

IndicatorDescription: Concentration of bacteria - fecal coliform and enterococci are human-health-related indicators of water quality. Fecal coliform bacteria are found in human and animal intestines and are associated with wastewater. Enterococci may be a more sensitive indicator of wastewater pollution in a saltwater environment.

Measures.how_calculated: Sampling sites were chosen based on historical data, open water sites (no tributaries) located near NYC Wastewater Resource Recovery Facility outfalls and landfill sites, boundary sites around New York City, and sites that have displayed historical water quality issues. Outliers were removed based on procedural justifications such as improper equipment calibration.
Measures.Sources: NYC DEP Historical Harbor Survey Data (Summer season data)

Measures.how_calculated: Sampling sites were chosen based on historical data, open water sites (no tributaries) located near NYC Wastewater Resource Recovery Facility outfalls and landfill sites, boundary sites around New York City, and sites that have displayed historical water quality issues. Outliers were removed based on procedural justifications such as improper equipment calibration.
Measures.Sources: NYC DEP Historical Harbor Survey Data (Summer season data)

Measures.how_calculated: NYS DEC standard: monthly geometric mean less than or equal to 200 cells/100mL from 5 or more samples
Measures.Sources: NYS DEC Regulations

Measures.how_calculated: NYS DEC standard: monthly geometric mean less than or equal to 2,000 cells/100mL from 5 or more samples
Measures.Sources: NYS DEC Regulations

Measures.how_calculated: NYS DEC standard: monthly geometric mean less than or equal to 35 cells/100mL; or single-sample maximum of 104 cells/100mL
Measures.Sources: NYS DEC Regulations

IndicatorDescription: Dissolved oxygen is essential for most aquatic life. It is an important indicator of overall water quality.

Measures.how_calculated: NYS DEC standard: 5.0 mg/L
Measures.Sources: NYS DEC Regulations

Measures.how_calculated: NYS DEC standard: 4.0 mg/L
Measures.Sources: NYS DEC Regulations

Measures.MeasureName: Dissolved oxygen (DO), Top of water column (mean)
Measures.how_calculated: Sampling sites were chosen based on historical data, open water sites (no tributaries) located near NYC Wastewater Resource Recovery Facility outfalls and landfill sites, boundary sites around New York City, and sites that have displayed historical water quality issues. Outliers were removed based on procedural justifications such as improper equipment calibration.
Measures.Sources: NYC DEP Historical Harbor Survey Data (Summer season data)

Measures.MeasureName: Dissolved oxygen (DO), Bottom of water column (mean)
Measures.how_calculated: Sampling sites were chosen based on historical data, open water sites (no tributaries) located near NYC Wastewater Resource Recovery Facility outfalls and landfill sites, boundary sites around New York City, and sites that have displayed historical water quality issues. Outliers were removed based on procedural justifications such as improper equipment calibration.
Measures.Sources: NYC DEP Historical Harbor Survey Data (Summer season data)

IndicatorName: Children with an asthma attack (past 12 months)
IndicatorLabel: Children with an asthma attack (past 12 months)
IndicatorDescription: Children ages 1 to 13 who have had an asthma attack in the past year. Asthma attacks are a measureable adverse health outcome of asthma.

Measures.MeasureName: Children with an asthma attack (past 12 months), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 1-13 years who reported having had an asthma attack in the past 12 months.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.MeasureName: Children with an asthma attack (past 12 months), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 1-13 years who reported having had an asthma attack in the past 12 months, divided by all children of the same ages, expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorName: Children in homes with visible mold or mildew (age 1-13)
IndicatorLabel: Children in homes with visible mold or mildew
IndicatorDescription: Children who live in homes with visible mold/mildew. Mold and mildew can trigger asthma attacks in children.

Measures.MeasureName: Children in homes with visible mold or mildew (age 1-13), Number
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 1-13 years living in private home sor apartments that report visible mold or mildew in their home in the past 12 months.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.MeasureName: Children in homes with visible mold or mildew (age 1-13), Percent
Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 1-13 years living in private home sor apartments that report visible mold or mildew in their home in the past 12 months., divided by all children of the same ages, expressed as a percent.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorDescription: Children ages 1 to 13 that currently have asthma. Not every asthma diagnosis is correct. The number of children who still have asthma is usually smaller than the number of children who have ever been diagnosed with asthma.

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 1-13 years who reported still having asthma. Denominator includes all children but only children who reported being previously diagnosed with asthma were asked.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

Measures.how_calculated: Estimated number of children ages 1-13 years who reported still having asthma, divided by all children of the same ages, expressed as a percent. Denominator includes all children but only children who reported being previously diagnosed with asthma were asked.
Measures.Sources: NYC KIDS Survey

IndicatorDescription: Farmers markets are a great source of fresh produce and other healthy food options and can help mitigate the negative effects of food deserts.

Measures.how_calculated: The number of farmers markets per neighborhood that are open for any period of the year.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) via NYC Open Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of farmers markets per neighborhood that are open for any period of the year, divided by the neighborhood area in square miles.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) via NYC Open Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of farmers markets per neighborhood that are open during the entire the year.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) via NYC Open Data

Measures.how_calculated: The number of farmers markets per neighborhood that are open during the entire year, divided by the neighborhood area in square miles.
Measures.Sources: NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) via NYC Open Data

IndicatorName: Rat indexing in Rat Mitigation Zones (RMZs)
IndicatorLabel: Rat indexing in Rat Mitigation Zones (RMZs)
IndicatorDescription: Rat indexing is a comprehensive approach for rat mitigation. In certain zones, every property is inspected every six months for signs of rats and the conditions that attract them.

Measures.MeasureName: Rat indexing in Rat Mitigation Zones (RMZs), Number of properties inspected
Measures.how_calculated: Number of properties inspected in an RMZ within a six-month period. Inspections are of all properties that have a tax lot, including privately-owned property, public property, parks, schools, and vacant lots.
Measures.Sources: Veterinary, Rodent, and Vector Surveillance System

Measures.MeasureName: Rat indexing in Rat Mitigation Zones (RMZs), Failed (any reason)
Measures.how_calculated: Percent of inspections that resulted in a failure for any reason, including active rat signs, in a given RMZ. Inspections are of all properties that have a tax lot, including privately-owned property, public property, parks, schools, and vacant lots.
Measures.Sources: Veterinary, Rodent, and Vector Surveillance System

Measures.MeasureName: Rat indexing in Rat Mitigation Zones (RMZs), Failed (active rat signs)
Measures.how_calculated: Percent of inspections failed for active rat signs (ARS) in a given RMZ. Inspections are of all properties that have a tax lot, including privately-owned property, public property, parks, schools, and vacant lots.
Measures.Sources: Veterinary, Rodent, and Vector Surveillance System

IndicatorDescription: Rat inspections are conducted for signs of rats and the conditions that attract them.

Measures.MeasureName: Rat inspections, Percent of properties inspected
Measures.how_calculated: Percent of properties inspected within a CD. Inspections are of all properties that have a tax lot, including privately-owned property, public property, parks, schools, and vacant lots.
Measures.Sources: Veterinary, Rodent, and Vector Surveillance System

Measures.how_calculated: Percent of properties that failed inspections for any reason, including active rat signs, garbage, or conditions that harbor rats, in a given CD. Inspections are of all properties that have a tax lot, including privately-owned property, public property, parks, schools, and vacant lots.
Measures.Sources: Veterinary, Rodent, and Vector Surveillance System

Measures.how_calculated: Percent of inspections failed for active rat signs (ARS) in a given CD. Inspections are of all properties that have a tax lot, including privately-owned property, public property, parks, schools, and vacant lots.
Measures.Sources: Veterinary, Rodent, and Vector Surveillance System

IndicatorDescription: Anaplasmosis is a tick-borne disease transmitted through the bite of an infected blacklegged tick. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, and fatigue. The majority of cases report a history of travel and outdoor exposures outside of New York City.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of cases meeting the?national case definition.
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

Measures.how_calculated: Crude Rate per 100,000 Population
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population using NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal estimates, updated April 2017.
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

IndicatorDescription: Lyme disease is transmitted through the bite of an infected blacklegged tick and is the most common tick-borne disease among New Yorkers. Symptoms can include rashes that look like a bulls-eye and fever, fatigue, headache, and muscle or joint pain. Most patients acquire this disease while traveling outside NYC. However, local cases are often reported in Staten Island. In 2022, an expected increase in cases was observed due to changes in the case definition.

Measures.how_calculated: Number of cases meeting the?national case definition.
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

Measures.how_calculated: Crude Rate per 100,000 Population
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

Measures.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population using NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal estimates, updated April 2017.
Measures.Sources: NYC DOHMH Bureau of Communicable Disease

IndicatorDescription: ED visits due to heat-related illnesses, such as heat stroke and heat exhaustion, represent part of the public health burden of extreme heat.

Measures.MeasureName: Heat stress: 5-year emergency department visits, Number
Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) over 5 years during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Measures.MeasureName: Heat stress: 5-year emergency department visits, Estimated annual rate
Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) over 5 years during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census

Measures.MeasureName: Heat stress: 5-year emergency department visits, Average annual age-adjusted rate
Measures.how_calculated: The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) over 5 years during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Measures.Sources: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data; United States Census
